title: EU consumers back call for more stringent eco-labels on confectionery and other food products - ConfectioneryNews.com
summary: The European Commission is considering proposals to stamp out misleading environmental claims, including a 'Product Environmental Footprint' methodology and a ban on new public labelling schemes unless developed at the EU level. Research from EIT Food, supported by the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, found that 67% of nearly 10,000 consumers surveyed from 18 European countries would use a universal, independent, and factually substantiated label for sustainable food products.
green_innovation: TRUE, The article describes a 'Product Environmental Footprint' methodology and a ban on new public labelling schemes unless developed at the EU level, which are green innovations because they contribute to environmental sustainability goals.
business_innovation: FALSE, The article does not describe a new or improved product or business process that differs significantly from the firm's previous products or business processes.
green_product: TRUE, The article describes a proposal for a universal, independent, and factually substantiated label for sustainable food products, which would be a green product because it is designed to reduce negative environmental externalities.
green_process: FALSE, The article does not describe a new or improved business process for one or more business functions that differs significantly from the firm’s previous business processes.
product_or_process: 'Product Environmental Footprint' methodology and a ban on new public labelling schemes unless developed at the EU level
greenwashing: The article does not describe an example of greenwashing.

title: Nestlé invests £7 million into new hard-to-recycle plastics plant - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Nestlé is investing £7 million into a breakthrough plastic recycling technology by Impact Recycling. The partnership aims to improve the UK's recycling capacity for flexible packaging, which currently has only an 8% recycling rate. Impact Recycling's technology separates and purifies mixed plastic waste into polyethylene (PE) and polypropylene (PP) pellets, which can be used to create new flexible products.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the technology reduces the negative environmental externalities of plastic waste by enabling the recycling of hard-to-recycle flexible plastics.
business_innovation: TRUE, because the technology is new and significantly improved over previous recycling processes, and has the potential to revolutionize the recycling industry.
green_product: TRUE, because the pellets created from the recycling process can be used to create new flexible products, reducing the need for virgin plastic production.
green_process: TRUE, because the recycling process minimizes environmental impacts by reducing plastic waste and conserving natural resources.
likely_naics_codes: ['326199 - Other Plastics Product Manufacturing', '322219 - Other Plastic Products Manufacturing', '326160 - Polystyrene Foam Product Manufacturing', '562920 - Solid Waste Collection']
greenwashing: FALSE, because the described innovation is a genuine green innovation with substantial environmental benefits.

title: PepsiCo pushes entrepreneurial collaboration as 'vital' APAC sustainability strategy - FoodNavigator-Asia.com
summary: PepsiCo launched a sustainability-focused accelerator program in the APAC region, with the goal of finding innovative solutions for sustainable packaging and other impactful climate actions. The program winner, Powered Carbon, developed a carbon capture and utilization technology that can be used to cultivate fungi for eco-friendly fertilizer production. PepsiCo is testing Powered Carbon's eco-friendly products on potato cultivation in its Shandong farm in China, with pilot results expected in Q4 2023.
product_or_process: Powered Carbon's carbon capture and utilization technology
likely_naics_codes: ['325199 - All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing', '325314 - Nitrogenous Fertilizer Manufacturing', '325998 - All Other Miscellaneous Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing', '562112 - Solid Waste Collection']
greenwashing: The article does not provide any evidence to suggest that Powered Carbon's carbon capture and utilization technology is an example of greenwashing.

title: Global Denim Jeans Strategic Market Report 2023-2030 - Denim Enters Dynamic Times with Innovations to Push ... - GlobeNewswire
summary: The report predicts that the global denim jeans market will reach $114.6 million by 2030, expanding at a CAGR of 6.3% from 2022 to 2030.  The market's growth is mainly attributed to the increasing demand for sustainable and eco-friendly fashion, rising disposable incomes, and growing urbanization, especially in developing countries.  Additionally, the report highlights the trend towards eco-conscious consumers and the adoption of sustainable practices such as circular denim and bioindigo dyeing techniques.

title: Mars rethinks recipes, ingredients on journey to Net Zero - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Mars, the company behind brands such as Ben's Original, Twix, and Mars bar, has committed to reach net zero emissions across its full value chain by 2050. As part of their plan to achieve this, Mars is developing new sustainable ingredients and reformulating products. One example is allulose, a natural sugar substitute that has a lower GHG footprint than traditional sugar. Mars is also working with third-party suppliers to develop new sustainable ingredients, such as Perfect Day's precision fermentation-derived dairy protein.
green_innovation: TRUE, Mars is developing new sustainable ingredients and reformulating products to reduce its GHG footprint.
business_innovation: TRUE, Mars is developing new ingredients and reformulating products to meet consumer demand for more sustainable products.
green_product: TRUE, Mars is developing new sustainable ingredients and reformulating products to reduce its GHG footprint.
green_process: FALSE, the article does not describe any new green processes.

title: Top 10 Best Paper Manufacturing Companies In India 2024 - Inventiva
summary: The Indian paper manufacturing industry is growing and is now dominated by companies that prioritize sustainability and technology. These companies are investing in research and development to create innovative and eco-friendly paper products and processes. They are also focusing on expanding their product portfolios and entering new markets.
